p.s: I know that for your year abroad after school which you're aiming at Germany you are highly considering to stay in Berlin.

So I found this article by Marina KarimbakiMarina Kormbaki Berlin spricht Englisch which was published in the Hannoversche Allgemeine Zeitung back in 2016 so I can list the positives and negatives for you choosing Berlin:
First of all she states that Berlin because more and more like other English speaking metropoles.
In the districts of Neukölln and Kreuzberg you may not even hear a German word.
That is because many there speak Turkish or Arabic what would be a negative for you as you can't relate to any of that.
But in the Neuköllner Wasserstraßenkiez English speaking is pretty normal.
On the other hand David Walker says that Berlin is a bibble inside of Germany that has nothing to do with German culture at all but because more international.
But again what's your positive is that you could easily get an English-speaking job and Berlin in comparison to other metropoles is so cheap.
Some people from aborad even open their own shops.
Also the rent is really affordable even if you live to the action and culture - not German culture though.
And here comes my own advice: If you want it really easy, go to Berlin.
It really is the best option for English speakers in Germany.

But if you want to experience real German culture I'm sure Berlin offers that in some parts too because it still has very impressive architecture you can also go to other big German cities like Munich, Hamburg or Cologne where the rents in particular districts are also affordable and you still get that touch of internationality.
